awd_titl_txt: AF:  Small:  Combinatorial Algorithms and Structure in Phylogeny:  A Chordal Graph Approach
awd_abstract_narration:
Combinatorial Algorithms and Structure in Phylogeny: A Chordal Graph Approach 
NSF:CCF 1017580
PI: Dan Gusfield, UC Davis
    The evolutionary history of a set of  organisms is described by a tree called an evolutionary, or phylogenetic tree.  Such trees display fundamental, evolutionary relationships between organisms, and are  also used to display information and relationships outside of  the field of evolution. as well.  The Multi-State Perfect Phylogeny (MPP) problem is  a computational and mathematical  problem arising from the construction of such evolutionary trees.   The MPP problem addresses  the need to represent rich, multi-state  properties of data in phylogenetic trees,  rather than properties that only have two states (for example, present or absent). The MPP problem was initially defined  in a 1974 paper that established a deep mathematical relationship between it and a subfield of  the mathematical field called  ``graph theory''.  Graph theory is the study of  collections of points and lines; the subfield of graph theory that is related to the MPP problem is called Chordal Graph Theory.  Although the connection between the MPP problem and chordal graph theory has been known since 1974,  that connection has not been widely used in the development of algorithms for the computational solution of  the MPP problem and  extensions of  the MPP problem. 
This project  focuses on exploiting  and extending recent advances in chordal graph theory to develop  practical computational methods to solve  Multi-State Perfect Phylogeny problems and extensions of those problems.  Building on recent work in the literature on chordal graph theory, the project will obtain new graph theoretic results for the MPP problem,  and will use those mathematical results to obtain practical algorithms for MPP problems.  This is a rare situation where a deep, elegant mathematical and algorithmic framework is available and appropriate for the study of an applied algorithmic problem.  The project combines research in computer science algorithms, graph theory, and discrete optimization theory to produce effective means for reconstructing evolutionary histories, and for understanding the underlying mathematical structure of such histories.  This theoretical work will be accompanied by the development of a suite of software tools that will be made available for other researchers interested in studying chordal graphs,  MPP problems, treewidth problems, and related problems.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

por.por_cntn:
This grant was focused on extending and applying a well-developed area in combinatorial mathematics, called Chordal Graph Theory, to help find efficient algorithms for building evolutionary trees over more complex data than is currently common.  The data is called `multi-state' because there is no bound on the number of states that a character can assume. That is in contrast to the more common bound of two states. Thus, the work was aimed at developing algorithms that are efficient for DNA and protein data, in particular, but more generally for any multi-state data. This work builds on a theorem proven about forty-five years ago that connects the fields of chordal graph theory with the field of multi-state phylogenetics.  However, the theorem only exposed the mathematical relationships, and had not been fully explored and exploited to develop efficient algorithms. Although the trees built through this approach are called `evolutionary trees', the algorithms have wide application beyond the study of evolution. Thus the work has potential impact in many parts of biology and medical studies, and in general data-analysis applications.  This research resulted in the solution of several open questions, and in the publication of thirteen papers, in the development and release of three major software suites,  in numerous university and conference presentations, and in the training of three students - one undergraduate, one graduate, and one post-graduate.

 


Last Modified: 05/18/2016
Modified by: Daniel Gusfield
